NEW CONVERSATION:
Persona: topics rather
Persona: I feel like I might be a victim of decision making paraysis again witht he topic
Persona: Since I am really afraid of choosing a topic that will not interst me
Persona: The passion multiplier is really large in most of the work that I do. So getting it right or wrong is big for me.
Persona: Also add Simulations to it
Persona: 🤞🤞🤞
Persona: hoping with my whole three hands you get it
Friend: I'll be honest. I have no idea what I've just read 🙃
Friend: but happy for you!
Persona: yeah its just my notes of named topics, we haven't picked a topic yet
Friend: no no, I know. I mean that I have little to no understanding of these topics
Friend: except for game theory perhaps, as long as it's the same game theory I'm thinking about
Friend: yeah no, that I totally get. that's what the past 6 months of my life have been all about basically
Persona: I would love to explain them to you. Business topics are not as hard than science-science in my opinion
Persona: I think it is what you are thinking about it, however, if we go with it, we would like to stay away from political aplications
Persona: and in retrospect, what you think of your topic choice?
Persona: I am actually conciously trying to train faster, intuitive decision making. As a wannabe founder this is very important, but its so hard when I've been taught to prioritize rationality, reasoning, seeking more information
Friend: oh no, it's the complete opposite for me. I guess I'm capable of comprehending those things, but it just goes into one ear and out of the other immediately. ask me a week later and I'll have no recollection of anything you said haha
Friend: I still love the topic, but was very wrong about the type of work I want to do. all my life I thought that since I'm more introverted, sth focused on data analysis would be good for me. turns out I'm far more social than I thought. sitting all day everyday in front of a screen made me absolutely miserable throughout that year
Friend: do you think the former is better? while I understand that it's important to be able to just take actions, because you wouldn't get anything done otherwise, I also believe that the issue with a lot of ent is just they're quite detached from reality. most of them fail after all
Persona: Then I shall tell it to each ear separetely
Persona: because data analysis was not fun enough or overall because not much human connection in front of the screen? There are some types of work, infamously what I did in my previous job, that was purely in front of the screen and purely of introvertive nature, that I was suprer miserable for two years. But then in other work I can absolutely thrive not talking to anyone and just working. Just to give you a perspective
Persona: My prev. job was translating SoMe texts from English to Lithuanian. I am just disgusted by the thought of it now, I could not focus, I kept checking phone every 5 mins, etc. But when it comes to programming, I literally forget other ppl exist, time passes instantly.
Persona: Of course you have to use a lot of logical thinking still. I think there may be multiple reasons why being able to make gut decisions can be really good for a founder. I came to realize this after having a mentoring session with one lady. And trust me, my mind at first was really against what she told me. But it also maybe more applicable to startup world, not sure of sciece world. Would love to tell you more about that too
Persona: I'll need to discover a way to close a leak in your ears when telling you those things haha
Friend: hm most of the time I was either reading papers, coding or writing, and really enjoyed each, time was passing almost too fast. yet it definitely felt like I was reliving the same day 250 times + that project was an old one, from pre-covid times, so I was rather detached from what everyone else was doing. and I'm driven not so much by achievements, but rather by passion and that childlike sense of awe about the world. if there's no one who matches my excitement about sth, it def dampens my spirit quite a bit and I tend to become disinterested
Friend: also I cannot be left alone for too long or my brain switches from outward mode to inward mode, and I get very weird very quickly haha. I kind of forget how to be a person
Friend: aaah I don't know. still not convinced. I trust no one in this world more than my gut instinct, but still think it's important to gather as much data as possible first, then do what feels right
Friend: oh god no. I'm not getting involved in diy closing of any leaks ever again
Persona: I was thinking about the "if there's no one who matches my excitement about sth" thing a bit. I actually may be dependent on this one aswell, and I think I end up trying to force it upon people. Perhaps I even showed you my weird AI pong experiment haha. I usually spam my best friend, who knows a bit of nerdy stuff, I don't know how sustainable is that cause I might be ultra annoying but he does not tell me.
Persona: Now I think that maybe I stopped that AI pong because I ran out of unique impressions from other people xd
Persona: this I totally get. It might be paradigm in the world about coding, data science and nerdy things. I really god damn want to find all the needed evidence to break this belief, but I am not getting close to this
Persona: at the company I work we have engineering team and sales team. The sales people are extreme extroverts. I could not believe people can be so extroverted, it came as a shock to me. They just never stop interacting. The engineers only talk to each other. Most of them never show up to friday bars and the one guy that does, he is like the cool engineer dude, I can still see that he is lonely sometimes in parties. I am in a position between both of them. And this position is so weird. So this might be an ultimate dilemma whether to pursue nerdy things or not
Persona: I just came back from my company retreat which held us in Sweden for a few days (and thus sorry for responding late, it was very intense) and I kept thinking about being inward and outward at the same time. I spent my holiday very inward and I am semi-inward at work and then tried to be outward but I can't just switch instantly and I had a bad experience.
Persona: Wonder if you thats also how you felt
Persona: I haven't tried to convince you yet. I am not sure if I should haha, I haven't tested it yet.
Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. So perhaps it's better to fail two startups in three years and learn so much for the third one, than spend multiple years looking for a perfect idea with no real-world experience.
Friend: AI ping pong. I actually do have a memory of looking at it, but don't remember what was that all about...what was that all about?
Friend: and he hasn't unfriended you yet. you must be doing something right 🤷‍♀️👏
Friend: you know, I think it may seem  it's a STEM people thing due to introverts being overrepresented in that group. I definitely do see people from other walks of life experience this as well
Friend: oh man, sales people are intense. cool when you want a fun night out, but I feel they talk at you and not to you most of the time. engineers are computer science and math/physics people - I have a special bond with those. may know them for 10 min, but it always feels like we've been friends for 10 years
Friend: the thing about being in-between - I get it. personally, I do have to go to different people for different things a lot, because I've never really been able to get all my social needs met by one friend group. love talking to nerds, but you can't really drag them downtown to a rave. love party people, but I don't know how to connect with them on a deeper level. sciencey people are awesome when I've just learnt about some cool study I want to discuss, but I'm not nearly as logical and grounded as them. once I started volunteering at cultural events here in cph, I've realized how much I missed the freedom and creativity of artsy people. and so on. I don't know if I belong everywhere or nowhere, but I guess it is what it is
Friend: but in your case it could be an asset. I guess if you want to be in charge of sth larger, you need to be able to communicate with all sorts of people
Friend: hahah, yes. it feels like I'm in some sort of a locked in syndrome. my brain is happy to finally encounter some people, but cannot remember for shit how a conversation works
Friend: the only successful form of treatment it to lie down on the floor with a beer and pitbull in the background. can't believe it's not socially acceptable at workplaces yet
Friend: I've just realized that we have different types of choices in mind. I was thinking more generally, and you're referring specifically to business decisions. when I make big decisions, they usually concern the important turns in the trajectory of my own life, so my most precious resource is time. cannot really afford to lose too much of that. but when it comes to money and other renewable things, yeah, I think it's easier to just fuck around and learn from experience (I know you still invest and lose time here, but I guess it's not the main concern)
Persona: ahahah I litetally laughed "with a beer and pitbull in the background". What a mix
Persona: Need to try the full treatment
Persona: we should hang out sometime
Persona: wait I will reply later, gtg a bit
Persona: I used an evolutionary algorhythm to train a neural network to play computer ping pong. It was not bad. I could still beat it sometimes and I wanted to optimize it further but I didnt manage to train it to think a few seconds ahead

Persona: I can recommend, I love it. I could try to copy mine (it would take some work with the mobile AppSheet integration and open banking setup), but honestly, its very well uncodumented, since I am the sole user of it, has some spaghetti google sheets formulas and probably some things that don't work 100%, so making something like that yourself is better. I just upgrade it from time to time to fit my needs.
Persona: I can just recomend some things that I found to really work well for me.
Persona: Also I think Google Sheets is a perfect development toolkit to build something where the only user is you. Its really flexible for expanding, although it has some soft limitations, where writing more complex operations is a pain if you want fast calculations, since AppsScript, which is more comprehensible works slower than native formulas.
Persona: For example the graph that I showed you is really expensive calculation wise. Takes around 30 second to calculate.
Persona: So I implemented caching to these calculations, which speeds it up, but still I have an enable button so if I am working on the spreadsheet, I don't keep in enabled.
Persona: Also UX posibilities is really limited, especially for data input, unless maybe make some script with low maintenance code that adds records in a convenient way. AppSheet is good making it easier to add through mobile, but AppSheet has some limitations I don't like
Persona: I was lookign into ReTool yesterday and they seemed very interesting, they are much more expandable, have a Google Sheets connection. Has good tools to build a decent UX. Recently added mobile support, so its effectively a better replacement for AppSheet. But pricing may be an issue, since they are b2b and free tear has some ambigious limits, like 1GB monthly bandwidth, that it kind of hard to understand, since idk how much bandwidth it uses lol, need to test.
Persona: The cool thing is that as long as you build the main logic inside Google Sheets, multiple tools can be used to extend the UX of the system and you can add functionality in Google Sheets, without necessarily needing to maintain the external tool, unless you want to integrate it to it.

Friend: Are the limitations user friendly input mostly?
Persona: User friendliness and convenience. F.e. after adding a new row, sometimes you just have to manually expand all of the cells from previous row, This is especially annoying if some inbetween columns are input columns.

And two obvious fixes dont work.
1) ArrayFormula at the top of the column to have an automatic column wide formula. That can work sometimes, but not always as I run into some limitations with them that I haven't found a workaround.
2) Separating input columns has a tradeoff, since at once glance, I would like to see some calculated columns and some input colums. I guess I can workaround by duplicating some of new clumns now I thought... Maybe worth doing it to increase convenience
Persona: f.e this
Persona: I have to manually expand all of the grayish columns and not expand the white one, since white ones are input columns and gray ones are formula columns
Persona: Thats the second limitation - columns can either be manual input or calculation. They can't be both, You need to make a separate column for that (like you can see my manual conversaion rate column)
Persona: Integration like AppSheet can solve that as they automatically expand selected columns when entries are added
Persona: And I have to have separate Input Amount and Final amount columns
Persona: Since input amount is not always the final amount if f.e. I want to track if I got a refund on something or someone payed me back for what I baught (say a friend asks to buy them some beers)
Persona: Map with lamba can fix that I think

Persona: Basically I only feel uncomfortable when my blood is involved in the situation. But this is also a bit complex. I would not mind seeing my blood like chilling somewhere, so a finger cut that I quickly cover does not bother me at all. So to be prescise, its the fact of knowing that I have less blood now that bothers me. As soon as I think some blood is drawn from me I start to feel shivers (even now as I am typing).
Persona: It would be probably really funny if you saw me getting a blood test. I always make sure I make good friends with the nurse so she gives me great treatment. Then I exaggerate how I don't like the sight of my blood and I never look to the blood that was drawn from me.
Persona: Once I haad a terrible experience. The nurse failed to take my blood like three times, the vein 'didn't work' or smth, no blood was coming. You can imagine how I felt.
Persona: But the blood tests are not really a big issue, not even an issue. The worst part is that I can never get myself to donate blood. My friends do it regularly and I always skip, cause I would not be able to live with the fact that I have less blood, even if it's temporary. In my mind I am like imagining air gaps in the blood vessels, as there is not enough blood to fill whole volume.

Persona: I didn't like obsidian because it has stupid functionality for block references. Its more page based.
Persona: And it also has much more primitived block embed functinality (make a editable reference to a block). You edit in point A, it changes in Point B and vice versa. On Logseq this is possible, fully native, and easy.
Persona: Thats the feature I was dreaming about in MindManager for so long
Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)
Persona: The only issue with Logseq is that its less stable and feels a little weirder and less polished than Obsidian. Obsidian is super smooth
Persona: Next semester I will try switching uni notes to Logseq, but I am a little anxious. There will be many improvements with that - like I can't wait till I can use block embeds, also I will be able to share my notes with other people in a standardized format. Search functionality is better too.
Persona: But I am anxious that the mindmap layout presentation will turn out to be much more superior to bullet list presentation when it comes to complex topics I will study. Also in Logseq there is less options for content visual customization, so making things standout is more limited (bolding, colors still work).
